question: What in thunderation -- Wait a minute -- stop -- All right -- What are you girls doin' way out here?
answer: Until you came along we were going to Sonora.

question: What do you know about that. Did you sell your place?
answer: Not exactly. They decided gambling and dancing were bad for people. Can I make it?

question: Why, back to Aspen, where you came from.
answer: Aspen doesn't want us Mr. Graham. They threw us out.

question: They shouldn't have done that.
answer: We tried to point that out. But there were some pretty nosey citizens who wouldn't listen to reason. They said Aspen had outgrown us. It's all right to play poker in your own home but not in a saloon.

question: I knew something would happen when they started puttin' up fences and passin' laws.
answer: Goodbye and thanks.

question: How does she draw?
answer: A little hot. Rate you're goin', we'll be here until winter. You're too old to watch such goin's on.

question: And I'm too young.
answer: That's right.

question: I don't see no sense to makin' people leave town if they don't want to leave.
answer: Don't you ever run down? You stick to your blacksmithin' and let me take care of Steve. We'll both take a look. Anything's better than listenin' to Sam. Don't forget to shoe the mule. Who are they?

question: Forster never did anyone any harm. But what's that got to do with me? I came into town from the south.
answer: This was smoulderin' on the fire.

question: I still don't see.
answer: I got it day before yesterday. Now are you interested? You should be. Maybe Lednov heard about that Sonora ranch of yours.

question: Maybe he did.
answer: We're going to look for him. Want to come along?

question: I've got eleven horses to get over the mountains before snow catches me and covers the feed.
answer: And that's more important than finding Lednov?

question: Like you said, maybe he knows where my ranch is. If he does, he'll be waiting on the porch.
answer: I'll drop the sheriff in Sonora a line to sort of look around for him.

question: Shells. How much for six boxes?
answer: You might tell a fellow things, 'specially if the fellow's your brother, seems to me.

question: Like what?
answer: Like why you're buyin' a whole slew of 30 30 shells all of a sudden.

question: I don't want to run short.
answer: You never said this Lednov's name before, that I can remember.

question: No call to. That jail looked pretty solid to me. How's she feel?
answer: Nice.

question: One he's got, more his size.
answer: But it's leaded up and anyway a 22's no good for real huntin'. You shoot a man with a 22 and where are you?

question: The thing to do is stick to rabbits.
answer: What was he in jail for?

question: You sure worry that bone. He killed a fellow.
answer: In a fight?

question: The other fellow wasn't even lookin'.
answer: This is an awful nice gun. Certainly come in handy when there's men around who shoot people that aren't lookin'.

question: I may as well buy it for him. Otherwise he'll be crying all the way over the hill.
answer: You must be plenty worried about Lednov sneakin' up on us. Think he will?

question: Yes.
answer: At the ranch maybe?

question: Maybe at the ranch. Maybe sooner than that.
answer: Do you have to be so close-mouthed? I'm your brother. And I'm ridin' with you. Remember?

question: All right. I'll tell you. Let's say this is the penitentiary. Here's Alder Crick. And here we are in Aspen. That's Sonora. motioning) Lednov gets out of jail and comes along here to Alder Crick. Then goes along here toward the Sonora road. That's Lednov! We come along here.
answer: And meet him there.

question: Unless the sheriff gets too close and he holes up. So let's go.
answer: Sure a lot of guys lookin' for Lednov.

question: Yeah -- and Lednov's only lookin' for one man. Me.
answer: Why?

question: He doesn't like me. What you eatin'?
answer: Lednov. I don't like him. Another one, Clay.

question: I was at first. Then I was hanging on. Are you going far?
answer: Yes, ma'am.

question: As far as -- Sonora?
answer: Just about.

question: We're going to Sonora, too, so that solves everything. We can ride in your wagon. We wouldn't think of asking you to take us for nothing. There's only four of us.
answer: I've got eleven horses.

question: They won't be riding in the wagon.
answer: Did you ever try taking a bunch of horses over Sonora Pass? It's quite a job.

question: You can't leave us here.
answer: Course I can't. I'll give you a lift to the first ranch.

question: What good is it going to do us to go to some ranch?
answer: You can stay here if you like.

question: We have to get to Sonora. There are jobs waiting for us there. We'll pay you for your trouble.
answer: I'm not running a stage line, ma'am, and I can't take a chance on losing the horses. When you're old enough to smoke, I'll tell you. Get the horses started on ahead, will you, Steve?

question: Come on, Honeybunch. We're changing trains. A nice, kind wrangler is letting us ride in his wagon... ...as far as the first ranch. From then on --
answer: What ranch?

question: What's the difference?
answer: Ask him what ranch --

question: There's a place down a ways, where you and the girls can wash some of that dust off.
answer: Thanks. And isn't there something we can do about supper -- or making the beds?

question: Steve and me, we use a saddle for a pillow and roll up in a tarp.
answer: But you eat, don't you?

question: Mostly, we open a can of beans and boil some coffee.
answer: Where do you keep the can opener?

question: In the grub box. Toward morning the dew gets kind of heavy so maybe you better fix up a bed under the wagon. Spread some bunch grass under the tarp and the ground won't be so hard.
answer: Marcia -- all of you. Come on.

question: Drop your gun.
answer: Drop yours. I'm gunshy.

question: Then don't come sneakin' around a man's camp.
answer: A fellow sees a fire go out all of a sudden, he don't take chances. My name's Clayton and I'm looking for someone. I found their surrey --

question: So did I. They were in it.
answer: She's a friend -- took off this morning sort of sudden while I wasn't around.

question: I'm glad you came along. My brother, Steve. I'm Phillips. I gave the girls a lift. Didn't know what else to do with them. Get your horse and come on. Here's a man says he's looking for you girls.
answer: Hello, Miss Wells.

question: Why didn't you say you wanted to get married back in Aspen. I told the man in Sonora there were four of us. If only three show up, he might call the whole deal off. We've got to stick together. Like we've always done.
answer: I've got a chance to get married.

question: That's what I'm gettin' at. It never works. Don't forget we were thrown out of Aspen.
answer: Jim doesn't care, do you, Jim?

question: And look at it this way. How about Jim -- it puts him in a sort of tough spot.
answer: I know what I'm doing. My folks got nothin' to do with it --

question: You've talked this over with them?
answer: They know about Marcia.

question: Would you like to learn them?
answer: I sure would.

question: Maybe I could start you out.
answer: That'd be swell. You know, you're an awful lot different than I thought you'd be. You're so nice.

question: Did someone say I wasn't nice?
answer: Oh no. Nobody said nothing to me. Only I got the idea that -- well Clay and me used to be walking through town and there was your place and through the window I could see you dancing, but Clay always took me over to the other side of the street.

question: Good night, Steve. There's a nice boy.
answer: Yeah.

question: That why you always took him on the other side of the street? Maybe I don't make the grade in some ways, but I know enough to teach a kid his letters.
answer: He doesn't know his letters, no -- but he knows the names of animals... he knows what roots to eat when you're clear out of food... He knows the difference between a possum and a coon just by lookin' at the tracks... more than most trappers know... and he can tell whether she'll rain or shine tomorrow by smelling the air tonight. There's a lot of things he doesn't know, I hope he'll never learn.

question: Like what?
answer: Like sticking his nose into other people's business.

question: Ma'am -- you shouldn't have run off like that. Why I was just about to give up lookin'. Come on, now. You can't stay here. There's snakes and it's cold and you'll just get sicker.
answer: I don't care.

question: Suppose that Lednov was to have found you, instead of me. Why you wouldn't have had a chance.
answer: I said I didn't care.

question: What's botherin' you, anyway? Runnin' off and worryin' people. Makin' it tougher on Clay than it is already.
answer: Don't ask me because I won't tell you! I won't tell anybody! Go away!

question: Don't act so -- crazy.
answer: I'm sorry. Let's go.

question: Want to take her off our hands?
answer: Who shot who?

question: Nobody. The light was bad. Steve's! What's she doin' runnin' around the country at night.
answer: I wouldn't know. Did you ask her?

question: All I can get out of her is she don't care about livin'.
answer: Look of things, she doesn't.

question: There was only three of them at first. I guess I lost my head.
answer: How'd you happen to miss?

question: They were quite a ways off and the wind was blowin'. I didn't have them to aim.
answer: Good thing you didn't.

question: Clay -- A man can't help gettin' excited once in a while.
answer: That's right, Steve.

question: Can I have my gun back?
answer: Sure. You'll find it under the wagon seat. Like I said before, a twenty- two's more your size.

question: Gee, I can't.
answer: Why not? You went farther than that last time.

question: I'm too old for it, Miss Wells... That's for little kids.
answer: Don't be silly... Nobody's too old to learn.

question: Get back to the horses. They're straggling.
answer: He's learning his letters.

question: Yeah. While the horses wander all over the country. Do like I said.
answer: Learnin' to read has nothing to do with the right or the wrong side of the street.

question: Are the horses stragglin' or aren't they?
answer: They're stragglin'.

question: This isn't like other trips we've taken. For one thing, we've got a wagonload of women. For another there's a guy wanderin' around hopin' to put a bullet in my back.
answer: Okeh, I was wrong. But you can't expect a fellow who never saw Lednov and never heard his name until a while ago to do too much worryin'. You've been sorta close mouthed about him.

question: I guess I have. You were pretty little when they locked him up. I don't suppose you even remember that time I was gone two months.
answer: Sure I remember. You went to Mexico lookin' for cattle.

question: You remember Jeff Rawson? -- We used to go fishing and hunting with him when you were so high.
answer: Sure I do. Went off down to Mexico or something...

question: That's what I told you then. Only he didn't. Lednov killed him.
answer: Oh... that's the time you went away.

question: I caught up with Lednov in Nogales. He didn't like the idea of comin' back across the border but he came. I turned him over to the sheriff and -- that's the story.
answer: Maybe you shoulda killed him.

question: Maybe I should. But I was never much on killin'. Anyway, he moved too quick and I just got him through the shoulder. Looks pretty peaceful up ahead.
answer: Yeah, it does.

question: My name's Wyatt. Certainly glad you boys dropped in.
answer: Those the only horses you got?

question: Why, yes. They're all I need...
answer: Mine's gone lame. Take a look at him. Go on, we haven't got all day.

question: Whoa, boy. Let's have a look. He dropped a shoe. You shouldn't be ridin' him.
answer: Put on another one.

question: That won't help the stone bruise. You ain't been around horses much, looks like.
answer: Will you quit gabbin' and do what you're told.

question: I'll have some more of that coffee.
answer: We got to get movin'.

question: What for?
answer: Because there's a man I want to see.

question: He can wait. Let's stay here until morning.
answer: I said let's go.

question: One night more won't matter. Your friend'll be there. Anyway I don't think so much of the idea of prowling around his ranch. He knows you're out so he ain't going to sit still for it.
answer: I said I had a guy to see and I'm going to see him. He gave me something once so I wouldn't forget.

question: Mr. Wyatt. Clay Phillips.
answer: You can light the lamp. I'm sure glad it's you. We were afraid those killers might come back.

question: Three men on matched roans?
answer: Yeah, how did you know?

question: I picked up some women on the road.
answer: Tell them to come on in.

question: But I'm going to have to leave 'em here. They're --- well they're not the sort of people you're used to.
answer: It doesn't matter who they are.

question: And one of 'em is sick.
answer: Why didn't you say so. Go right out and get her. Ed. build the fire up.

question: So that was why she tried to run away.
answer: Didn't you know she had a father and mother out here?

question: I didn't know anything about her except she wanted a job because some man had left her stranded. I couldn't leave her in the street. Let's go.
answer: Hold on.

question: We can't stay here!
answer: It's a long walk back to Aspen.

question: Coffee?
answer: No, thanks. I hope we won't be a burden to them.

question: I hope so, too. If you're figuring on asking me to take you, it's no use.
answer: A time like this people ought to be alone. Having us around is going to make it sort of hard on 'em.

question: I'm sorry, but that's how it's got to be.
answer: I suppose it is.

question: And it's not only because the trip's a tough one --
answer: You don't have to explain. Did I tell you how grateful I am for what you've done?

question: I couldn't leave you sitting by the road.
answer: You could have treated us like they did in Aspen. No. You wouldn't do a thing like that -- it isn't in you to be mean or cruel.

question: No man who brings up a kid like you've brought up Steve could ever be cruel to people. I hope you get everything you want out of life --
answer: Thanks.

question: You've earned it -- the horse ranch on the Toulomoe -- the girl in the spotted gingham.
answer: The who?

question: You should know. She's in your dream. Ever since you've looked after Steve you've had the dream -- a ranch on the river -- good grass, good water, barn corral and house --- that part you've shared with Steve. The girl in gingham you plan sneakin' in when he isn't looking.
answer: Go on. Tell me more about her.

question: She wears this gingham dress -- cooks popovers -- makes jam in season -- makes her own soap from pig fat and wood ashes and has cheeks the color of red apples.
answer: I'll make the soap myself.

question: But the rest is right.
answer: Will she be dark or fair?

question: How long do you think we'll have to stay here?
answer: Until Pa gets around to driving us to Minden.

question: We don't want to go there.
answer: No we don't. But that's where we're going. From Minden we take a stage to Reno, then another one over to Auburn and another one to Placerville. Then it's a day's trip to Sonora.

question: Clay could save us an awful lot of time.
answer: He certainly could. About a month.

question: What are you waiting for? Do something. You're not giving up?
answer: How many ways can a man say no.

question: Maybe I better start working on him.
answer: You'd think he'd do it for Elaine's sake, at least...

question: You're worn out. Now don't argue. You've got two able- bodied girls to help you so take advantage of it. And don't let me catch you touching the dishes. Well -- it's going to be good for all of us -- having a nice long rest here. After all -- Sonora will still be there next month. Maybe we can rehearse a new number -- try it out on your folks.
answer: Helen -- why don't you and Mary go on with Clay?

question: He won't take us. Don't you want us around?
answer: Of course I do -- but it'd be better for you -- and the house is kind of small --

question: If you're worried about Mary and me talkin' too much, don't. No matter how many questions your old man asks. We know how to keep our mouths shut.
answer: It isn't that --

question: Don't talk -- eat -- we want to get you well quick as we can so we can all get out of here.
answer: But I want to stay.

question: Drink this and stop being silly. Why would anyone want to live in this place. You might as well be dead and buried. Nothing to do but look at mountains. In a week you'd be talking to yourself. Maybe that's what got you started in the first place.
answer: I'm not going anywhere. I'm staying here where I belong.

question: Not if I know Mary. When she rides into Sonora, you'll be with her. And mighty glad to be there after this. I don't see how you stood it as long as you did.
answer: Stop it -- stop it.

question: Darling -- now I've got you all upset.
answer: Go away -- please.

question: That's right -- you go back to sleep. Tomorrow when you feel better things will look a whole lot different. Don't you worry about anything -- Mary's going to talk things over with your folks --
answer: She mustn't -- don't you let her --

question: There, there. Don't you upset yourself --
answer: If she says anything to them I'll kill her. I don't want to leave you, ever.

question: You were right -- a man has only so many no's in him. But he had me worried -- that last one sounded so final.
answer: It's a lot tougher than I figured. Knowin' my letters is one thing. But makin' sense out of words is harder'n trackin' weasel after rain. -- and even if I do learn to read, what use'll it be? I'm goin' to live on a ranch!

question: There's plenty of use for reading -- you'll see.
answer: U-n-i-c-o-r-n-... What in heck's that?

question: Unicorn -- a kind of animal --
answer: What do they look like?

question: Hmmm... sort of like a horse -- with a horn in the center of its forehead.
answer: Horses with horns! Huh! Do we have 'em in Nevada?

question: No.
answer: How about California?

question: Would they be good to eat? Kind of tough, I guess... But you're not liable to hunt them -- I don't think there's any alive now, anyways -- and I'm not sure but I don't think there ever were...
answer: Then if they wasn't alive, how can they be an animal?... An' if you can't hunt 'em and even if you could they'd be tough, what's the use of knowin' how to spell them?

question: You don't read to fill your stomach... Poetry, for instance. All the poems in the world wouldn't fill you half as much as a bowl of eatmeal -- but they make you feel good.
answer: I feel good anyways.

question: Nobody's gonna catch him sleeping. Don't worry about him.
answer: Oh, I wasn't worrying. I saw him saddling up and thought he was ready to leave.

question: You were worryin'. Sometimes not knowin' how to read has its points. You can't read books so you look at people and figure 'em out.
answer: And you've got me all figured out?

question: Sure. I'll fix us somethin' to eat. Like when you were standin' there looking after Clay. I knew right off what you were thinking. Because I've been watching you.
answer: You were supposed to be reading words.

question: She was only teasin'.
answer: Oh, sure.

question: Let me do that.
answer: I like to do things for you. Didn't you know?

question: Don't you trust me?
answer: Not on this trail, I don't. I've been over it before. Anyway, you ought to be pretty sleepy. Why don't you climb in back.

question: I like to see where I'm going.
answer: Did you ever care where you were goin' or where you'd been?

question: Maybe not! But I want to get there in one piece. Why did you change your mind about bringing us along?
answer: Why do you think?

question: I don't know. I thought I did. Now I'm not sure. I thought it had something to do with me.
answer: Oh, it did. It had a great deal to do with you.

question: Just how do you mean that?
answer: You know so much about me -- figure it out.

question: My name's Fowler. I'm camped up a ways.
answer: Clay Phillips of Aspen. Been havin' trouble?

question: Nope. But I don't want any.
answer: Neither do we. That's why we took this trail instead of the main road, and drove all night.

question: You got no business snoopin' around --
answer: Me snoopin'? I came down here to take a bath. That something I shouldn't see?

question: No. But it's mine and I didn't want anyone foolin' with it.
answer: What is it?

question: Just a thing I was workin' on.
answer: The way you act, it must be something pretty secret.

question: Go on. Take your bath. I'll beat it.
answer: You wouldn't have a smoke on you, would you? Thanks.

question: That sure smells good.
answer: I like it.

question: Up here in the hills, a man gets a hankering to smell powder.
answer: Then why stay in the hills. That why?

question: All right you don't love me. So let it go at that.
answer: What did you expect? Speeches I don't mean?

question: I don't expect anything. A minute ago I hadn't cuite waked up. I'm awake now. Go on. Say what you want to say. I'll listen.
answer: If it's pretty speeches you want, you won't be hearing them. Even when I mean 'em, they don't come easy.

question: Save 'em for the girl in gingham. Just tell me I'm not good enough for you. Go on. Say a woman like me can't change.
answer: All right -- it's said!

question: Mary -- Are you all right?
answer: No, I'm not all right. I'm soaked and I hit myself against that rock.

question: I suppose that's my fault.
answer: All my clothes --

question: What do you want?
answer: I saw your fire and dropped by to say hello.

question: Well, say it.
answer: What's the matter -- restless?

question: Yes, people make me restless.
answer: Even women?

question: There aren't any women here.
answer: I suppose that's your wagon in the river.

question: Some people who went by this way lost it. Two men and some women. They packed their stuff on horses and went on.
answer: And you're all alone.

question: Yeah.
answer: Suppose I take a look.

question: Let him alone! Kick a guy, would you! You scum! You won't do any kickin' when they come back. You dirty murderers... killin' people when they're sleepin'...
answer: How do you know who we are?

question: Everybody knows --
answer: Who brought you here? You said somebody was comin' back -- who's comin' back?

question: Stop it -- Clay Phillips.
answer: Where is he?

question: Up the trail.
answer: How far up the trail?

question: Maybe you and me better split up when we hit Sonora.
answer: All right, I hurt your feelings. But you know better than to go lightin' fires.

question: That ain't why. I just figure it's about time to start runnin' my own life.
answer: Maybe you're not hungry, but I am. Come on. We got a couple hours to eat and get some sleep.

question: I'll eat when I'm good and ready.
answer: Kind of feeling your oats this morning. I haven't laid a hand on you for quite a while, but that doesn't mean you're too old.

question: You ain't even man enough to own up when you're wrong. Go on, hit me.
answer: Sit down and eat. Till I say the word, you're doing what you're told.

question: You oughta say you're sorry -- that's what you oughta do.
answer: You keep your nose out of my life, young fella.

question: Maybe I haven't lived as long as you have, but I know a sight more about people and I wouldn't talk to a mule like you talked to her and, if I did, I'd say how sorry I was. I'd be man enough to do that.
answer: I said keep your nose out of my life. No kid is going to tell me how to run it.

question: What did you come back for?
answer: Like I told you, half those horses are mine. I'm makin' sure they get to the ranch safe. So let's quit arguing and do whatever you figure on doin'.

question: Is that the only reason you came back?
answer: Sure. What other reason would there be?

question: How's that?
answer: Kind of sore.

question: You'll live.
answer: Guess maybe I'm old enough to hold my own in a fight, huh?

question: Yeah -- but don't make a habit of it.
answer: So -- maybe I'm old enough to tell you how to run your life?

question: I guess so -- but don't make a habit of it.
answer: Well, then, I know it takes three -- four weeks for you to come round to admit when you're wrong... But by that time she's liable to be in China...
